text.p: German telecommunications group Deutsche Telekom AG said on Tuesday that the 1.4 million subscribers to its online service T-Online would in future have access to the Microsoft Network.

In an extension of a cooperation agreement between Telekom and the U.S. software group, content -- online magazines and so-called chat forums -- from Microsoft Network (MSN) will be integrated in T-Online.

"Microsoft is an ideal expansion of T-Online with its software competence and know-how in the area of content," Telekom chairman Ron Sommer told a news conference ahead of the CeBIT information technology trade fair in Hanover.

Sommer said that with the next version of T-Online software, to be made available this week at CeBIT, subscribers to the service would be able to call up MSN content without first leaving T-Online and dialling up MSN.

The number of T-Online subscribers rose 40 percent last year to 1.4 million at the end of 1996. Most of the subscribers access the service over Telekom's high-speed Integrated Digital Services Network (ISDN).
Telekom board member in charge of residential customers said a total of 4.6 million ISDN channels have been sold in Germany, of which 1.6 million were accounted for by residential users.
ISDN allows online users to access the Internet at speeds of as much as three to four times that of conventional analogue modems.

"I am very happy about the promising partnership between Microsoft and Deutsche Telekom - the leading online provider in Europe," said Microsoft chief Bill Gates in a written statement distributed at the news conference.
T-Online has until now provided its subscribers with software for viewing pages on the World Wide Web -- a so-called browser -- from Microsoft competitor Netscape Communications.
It was not immediately apparent if T-Online would now make Microsoft's browser, the Internet Explorer, available to its subscribers.
